passages.text: 4452.T 4452 JP / EQUITY: JAPAN TOILETRIES & COSMETICS
We forecast profit growth driven by ongoing price hikes, project more share buybacks through 27/12
We reiterate our Buy rating; we expect Japan to drive earnings and also factor in share buybacks from 26/12

We reiterate our Buy rating; we expect Japan to drive earnings and also factor in share buybacks from 26/12We raise our earnings forecasts for Kao on the prospect of improved margins thanks to sustained price hikes and growth in mainstay brands at the global consumer care (GC) business in Japan. We forecast operating profits of ¥166.5bn in 25/12 (up 14% y- y) and ¥185.1bn in 26/12 (up 11%). We also assume annual share buybacks of ¥80bn through 27/12, taking into account Kao's high levels of cash & equivalents as a result of improved margins. The GC business overseas has been problematic, but restructuring of the earnings base is yielding results, and we still see upside versus our forecasts if efforts to increase sales of mainstay UV care products pay off. We reiterate our Buy rating. We obtain our target price of ¥7,850 by multiplying our 26/12 EPS forecast of ¥307.8 by a P/E of 25- 26x (previously 28- 29x our 25/12 EPS forecast). This represents a 15% premium over the average P/E of about 22x for toiletries companies under our coverage. We had previously valued the shares at a 20% premium to the benchmark average, but we now narrow this premium to reflect a smaller gap in profit growth rates versus the benchmark.

GC business in Japan: We forecast profit growth due in part to ongoing price hikes Many categories within the Japanese toiletries market are dominated by a small number of producers, making it relatively easy to push through price hikes. The company implemented another \((10 - 15\%)\) price hike for detergent and other products at end- June 2025. We envision sustained earnings growth as a result of ongoing price increases, including via the launch of high- priced products in categories such as UV and hair care.
Overseas GC business: Progress with rebuilding earnings base, but clear issues with sales growth

Overseas GC business: Progress with rebuilding earnings base, but clear issues with sales growthEarnings in the overseas GC business have been improving steadily thanks to structural reforms in Asia and Europe, and the company is now in a period of transition toward top- line growth. We envision modest earnings growth on increased distribution of UV care products to major retail chains in the health beauty care business (especially in Europe and the Americas), as well as new product launches and an overhaul of marketing.

Shareholder returns: We forecast share buybacks of ¥80bn per year through 27/12 Major capex under the current medium- term business plan, K27, has run its course, and we expect cash & equivalents to substantially exceed annual working capital as profitability improvements improve Kao's ability to generate operating cash flow.
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates (also see "Other notes" in the "Key data" section)

Largest toiletries company in Japan. From its origins in Kao Soap, also produces upstream chemical inputs such as surfactants. Has large portfolio ranging from laundry and household detergents, diapers, and feminine hygiene products through to cosmetics and hair care products. Main brands include Biore, Attack, Merries, and Magiclean.

We obtain our target price of \(7,850 by multiplying 26/12 EPS forecast of\) 307.8 by a P/E of 25- 26x. The fair- value P/E we apply is a roughly 15% premium over the average of about 22x on 20/12 forecasts for the five toiletries companies we cover (Kao, Lion, Kobayashi Pharmaceutical, Pigeon, and Unicharm). We forecast an operating profit CAGR of about 7% through 29/12 (over the end- 26/12 baseline), which is a little higher than the benchmark average of 6%. We also see good prospects for further shareholder returns now that sustained price hikes and restructuring have boosted the likelihood of medium- term earnings growth, and because improved earnings have enhanced the company's ability to generate operating cash flow.

Factors that could cause the share price to move below our target price include: (1) increased downward pressure on prices because of an economic downturn in Japan; and (2) a sharp deterioration in the COGS ratio because of sharp rises in input costs.

Core operating profits are operating profits minus gains/losses stemming from non- recurring factors. As the company is only using operating profits for 24/12 and providing y- y comparisons against 23/12 core operating profits, we do the same. Our forecasts assume annual share buybacks of \(\) 80bn\(in 25/12 - 27/12.\)

ESG strategy Kirei Lifestyle Plan established and efforts stepped up. Numerical targets for around 2030 being promoted. Aiming for carbon zero in terms of E, use of monitoring technology to provide personalized services in terms of S, collaboration with partners and outside parties, for example via the open digital concept, rather than reliance on itself, in terms of G.

We think the company will have its work cut out to achieve the target of record- high profits in 27/12, and we think it will have to provide a certain level of shareholder returns to achieve the 27/12 ROIC target of \(11\%\) .

We reiterate our Buy rating on Kao. We obtain our target price of ¥7,850 by multiplying our 26/12 EPS forecast of ¥307.8 by a P/E of 25- 26x. The fair- value P/E we apply is a roughly \(15\%\) premium over the average of about 22x on 26/12 forecasts for the five toiletries companies we cover: Kao, Lion [4912], Kobayashi Pharmaceutical [4967], Pigeon [7956], and Unicharm [8113]. (Our previous fair- value P/E of 28- 29x represented a \(20\%\) premium over the 25/12 benchmark average.) We forecast an operating profit CAGR of about \(7\%\) through 29/12 (over the end- 26/12 baseline), which is a little higher than the benchmark average of \(6\%\) . We think the stock deserves to trade at a premium of around \(15\%\) as we believe Kao can enhance shareholder returns as planned given improved prospects for medium- term earnings growth on sustained price hikes and restructuring, and because stronger earnings have boosted its ability to generate operating cash flow. We reduce the premium we apply to reflect a smaller gap in profit growth rates versus the benchmark average.

Kao's share price had been solid prior to the COVID- 19 pandemic, underpinned by earnings growth driven by the GC business in Japan. This in turn reflected a shift to products with high added value and moves to tap inbound demand. However, the share price has fallen since the start of the pandemic on the disappearance of inbound demand, fiercer competition in cosmetics and disposable diapers in China, and weak earnings at the GC business in Japan amid rising input costs. The share price is now recovering as the company has started to see results from the structural reforms it announced in 2023, including strategic price hikes and a review of invested capital.

Since 2013, the stock has traded at a one- year forward P/E of 18- 28x, versus the benchmark average of 23x. The stock has historically traded at a discount to the sector average P/E, but this is because of inferior potential for overseas earnings growth. However, while earnings have flagged in recent years due to a lackluster performance by overseas operations amid fiercer competition, we see little downside risk to valuations as we think that improved earnings capacity in Japan is offsetting this weakness and because we forecast record- high profits over the medium term.
Fig. 1: Operating profits and share price
Fig. 2: One-year forward P/E
Note: Note: The five toiletries companies are Kao, Lion, Kobayashi Pharmaceutical, Pigeon, and Unicharm. Weighted by market cap. Source: Nomura, based on Bloomberg data

Earnings in Japan had been sluggish since the start of the COVID- 19 pandemic because of rising input costs and the disappearance of inbound demand, but operating profits have improved substantially thanks to restructuring and price hikes implemented since 2022. Many categories within the Japanese toiletries market (including laundry detergent, where Kao holds the top share) are dominated by a small number of producers, creating a virtuous cycle in which companies are able to push through price hikes in their areas of strength. We envision ongoing earnings growth thanks to sustained price hikes, including additional price increases of \(10 - 15\%\) in the fabric & home care segment from end- June 2025, and the launch of high- priced merchandise in the UV and hair care product categories as well. In 25/12, we expect the cosmetics segment to be profitable at the operating level for the first time since 19/12 (when we estimate the segment had profits of around ¥29.0bn and an operating margin of about \(12\%\) ). Efforts to improve efficiency by cutting brands and headcount have started to bear fruit, but we forecast an operating margin of only around \(4\%\) in 25/12. Kao is due to hold a strategy briefing for the cosmetics business on 19 September, and we will be focusing on growth strategies for when restructuring has run its course.

The overseas GC business accounted for only around \(20\%\) of GC business operating profits in 24/12, and we regard overseas earnings growth as an issue for Kao. Restructuring measures (such as withdrawal from disposable diaper production in China in 2023 and organizational reforms at the health beauty care business in Europe in 2024) have resulted in cost efficiency gains and associated improvement in earnings. As a consequence, we think Kao is making progress in building an earnings base that can generate future earnings growth. The challenge going forward will be to achieve profit growth via top- line growth. In Europe and the Americas in particular, performance has been mixed even among similar categories, with weak sales for long- standing brands such as Goldwell and Jergens, but strong sales for brands acquired in recent years, such as Oribe and Bondi Sands. Kao management is aware of these issues, which it plans to address by launching new products and through the horizontal roll- out of new marketing strategies from H2 onward. While we do not currently envision any major profit growth at the overseas health beauty care business (partly due to proactive marketing spend), we are starting to see results from initiatives such as getting major Western retail chains to stock Kao's mainstay UV care products. Accordingly, we see upside versus our earnings forecasts if increased brand awareness and marketing initiatives translate into further sales growth.
Fig. 3: Operating profits in Japan by segment

Note: Segment profits are Nomura estimates. Method of booking profits changed as a result of transfer pricing taxation adjustments in 2023, resulting in a lack of continuity with 2022 and earlier. Consumer products business was renamed as global consumer care business in 2025. Source: Company data, Nomura estimates
Fig. 4: Impact of input costs and price hikes
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates
Fig. 5: Japanese CPI
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications' Statistics Bureau data
Fig. 6: Operating profits by overseas region

When reporting 25/12 Q2 results, Kao also announced its first share buyback in three years. The planned buyback of up to \(\yen 80bn\) exceeds our assumption of \(\yen 50.0bn\) . We now expect the company to continue with share buybacks of \(\yen 80bn\) a year through 27/12, when the K27 medium- term business plan ends. This is because we expect cash & equivalents to substantially exceed annual working capital over the next two years, as major capex under the current medium- term business plan has run its course, and as we expect profitability improvements to boost Kao's ability to generate operating cash flow. Also, we think Kao would struggle to meet its 27/12 ROIC target of \(11\%\) without further buybacks.

Kao's order of priorities for cash allocation is: (1) investment including M&A, (2) shareholder returns, and (3) share buybacks. The current medium- term business plan, K27 (23/12- 27/12), calls for (1) capex of \(\yen 360bn\) (excluding M&A). As Kao's plan was to invest around \(\yen 225bn\) through 25/12, we assume an average of about \(\yen 70bn\) from 26/12 onward. The startup of a new US chemical plant means that major investment planned for this period is now largely complete. In terms of (2), the company plans to raise dividends for a 36th straight year in 25/12, the longest such stretch for a Japanese company, and to continue raising dividends thereafter. On (3), even if the company continues to carry out \(\yen 80bn\) in annual share buybacks through 2027, it will still have cash & equivalents of at least \(\yen 300bn\) at the end of each fiscal year, more than sufficient for annual working capital of around \(\yen 250bn\) .

Cash allocation is currently based on the operating cash flow generated each fiscal year; again, there was no mention of the balance sheet this time around. As Kao has declared that it has adequate financial health, we await further disclosures on shareholder returns.
Note: We assume share buybacks of \(\yen 80\) per year in 25/12-27/12. Source: Company data, Nomura estimates
Fig. 8: ROE and ROIC
Note: ROIC figures are Nomura estimates/forecasts, based on calculation methods that differ from the company's. Source: Company data, Nomura estimates

Q2 operating profits of \(\yen 38.3bn\) (up \(7\%\) y- y) were in line with our forecast of \(\yen 38.9bn\) and look to have beaten guidance by about \(\yen 1.0bn\) . Operating profits were better than we expected in Japan thanks to solid sales of detergents and cost efficiency gains, but worse than we expected in Asia and Europe because of stiffer competition and weak sales as a result of cooling consumer sentiment. Kao raised its full- year operating profit guidance to \(\yen 165.0bn\) (up \(13\%\) ), mainly to reflect strong performance in Japan.

We revise up our 25/12 operating profit forecast from \(\yen 164.6bn\) to \(\yen 166.5bn\) (up \(14\%\) y- y). In view of Q2 results, we raise our forecast for the GC business in Japan by \(\yen 6.0bn\) and lower our forecasts for the overseas GC business and chemicals business by \(\yen 3.9bn\) and \(\yen 0.7bn\) , respectively. At the GC business in Japan, we expect the hot weather and price hikes since July to drive increased sales for new sunscreen and hair care products in the health beauty care segment, also boosting sales of detergents and other fabric & home care segment products. We also raise our forecasts for the cosmetics business to reflect growth in mainstay brands and cost efficiency gains stemming from restructuring. In the overseas GC business, we retain our profit forecasts for the Americas, but lower them for the hygiene living care business in Asia to reflect fiercer price competition and a downturn in consumer spending in Indonesia as a result of economic slowing. We also lower our forecasts for Europe to reflect a loss of competitiveness caused in part by slow progress with hair color product revamps.

We forecast 26/12 operating profits of \(\yen 185.1bn\) (up \(11\%\) y- y). As in 25/12, we expect the GC business in Japan to drive earnings, with operating profits of \(\yen 121.1bn\) (up \(13\%\) y- y). In Japan, we expect profit growth to be driven by increased profits at the hygiene living care business as sanitary product margins benefit from changes in the composition of feminine care products, and as the company continues to implement price hikes in the fabric & home care business. We also expect earnings at the health beauty care and cosmetics businesses to benefit from increased sales and cost efficiency gains for core brands, stemming from brand concentration following the completion of portfolio reforms. We expect overseas GC business operating profits to rise \(19\%\) y- y to \(\yen 30.0bn\) . While we expect Kao to continue investing in growth at the health beauty care business in Europe and the Americas, we think it will be able to generate cost efficiency gains via organizational reforms as well as growth in UV and other skincare products, areas where the company has been stepping up efforts. We also expect a global boost of \(\yen 6.5bn\) from lower prices for inputs such as crude oil and palm oil, which should buoy earnings both in Japan and overseas.
Fig. 9: Quarterly earnings estimates

Note: 24/12 (old) and 24/12 (new) show figures before and after segment changes. 24/12 (new) figures are Nomura estimates. Quarterly profits by region are Nomura estimates. Source: Company data, Nomura estimates.

Valuation Methodology We obtain our target price of \(\yen 7,850\) by multiplying our 26/12 EPS forecast of \(\yen 307.8\) by a P/E of 25- 26x. The fair- value P/E we apply is a roughly \(15\%\) premium over the average of about 22x on 26/12 forecasts for the five toiletries companies we cover (Kao, Lion, Kobayashi Pharmaceutical, Pigeon, and Unicharm). We forecast an operating profit CAGR of about \(7\%\) through 29/12 (over the end- 26/12 baseline), which is a little higher than the benchmark average of \(6\%\) . We also see good prospects for further shareholder returns now that sustained price hikes and restructuring have boosted the likelihood of medium- term earnings growth, and because improved earnings have enhanced the company's ability to generate operating cash flow.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Factors that could cause the share price to move below our target price include: (1) increased downward pressure on prices because of an economic downturn in Japan; and (2) a sharp deterioration in the COGS ratio because of sharp rises in input costs.

A rating of 'Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Neutral', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to perform in line with the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Reduce', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Suspended', indicates that the rating, target price and estimates have been suspended temporarily to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies. Securities and/or companies that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'No rating' are not in regular research coverage. Investors should not expect continuing or additional information from Nomura relating to such securities and/or companies. Benchmarks are as follows: United States/Europe/Asia ex- Japan: please see valuation methodologies for explanations of relevant benchmarks for stocks, which can be accessed at: http://go.nomuranow.com/research/m/Disclosures; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia, unless otherwise stated in the valuation methodology; Japan: Russell/Nomura Large Cap.

A 'Bullish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to outperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Neutral' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to perform in line with the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Bearish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to underperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. Sectors that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'N/A' are not assigned ratings. Benchmarks are as follows: United States: S&P 500; Europe: Dow Jones STOXX 600; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia. Japan/Asia ex- Japan: Sector ratings are not assigned.

A Target Price, if discussed, indicates the analyst's forecast for the share price with a 12- month time horizon, reflecting in part the analyst's estimates for the company's earnings. The achievement of any target price may be impeded by general market and macroeconomic trends, and by other risks related to the company or the market, and may not occur if the company's earnings differ from estimates.

An individual name printed next to NOI on the front page of a research report indicates that this document is a translation of a research report issued by NOI in the PRC. In all other cases, this document is prepared by Nomura Group or its subsidiary or affiliate (collectively, "Offshore Issuers") that is not licensed in the PRC to provide securities research. In addition, all products carry the risk of losses owing to price fluctuations or other factors. Fees and risks vary by product. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract, listed securities documents, or prospectuses. Transactions involving Japanese equities (including Japanese REITs, Japanese ETFs, and Japanese ETNs, Japanese Infrastructure Funds) are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.43\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(\) 2,860\(tax included) for transactions of\) \ \(200,000\) or less). When Japanese equities are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Japanese equities carry the risk of losses owing to price fluctuations. Japanese REITs carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in price and/or earnings of underlying real estate. Japanese ETFs and ETNs carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in the underlying indexes or other benchmarks. Japanese Infrastructure Funds carry out the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in price and/or earnings of underlying infrastructures.

Transactions involving foreign equities are subject to a domestic sales commission of up to \(1.045\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (which equals the local transaction amount plus local fees and taxes in the case of a purchase or the local transaction amount minus local fees and taxes in the case of a sale) (for transaction amounts of \(\) 750,000\(and below, maximum domestic sales commission is\) \ \(7,810\) (tax included)). Local fees and taxes in foreign financial instruments markets vary by country/territory. When foreign equities are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Foreign equities carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as price fluctuations and foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

Margin transactions are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.43\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(\) 2,860\(tax included) for transactions of\) \ \(200,000\) or less), as well as management fees and rights handling fees. In addition, long margin transactions are subject to interest on the purchase amount, while short margin transactions are subject to fees for the lending of the shares borrowed. A margin equal to at least \(30\%\) of the transaction amount (at least \(33\%\) for online transactions) and at least \(\) 300,000\(is required. With margin transactions, an amount up to roughly\) 3.3x the margin (roughly 3x for online transactions) may be traded. Margin transactions therefore carry the risk of losses in excess of the margin owing to share price fluctuations. For details, please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as listed securities documents or documents delivered before making a contract.

Transactions involving convertible bonds are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.10\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(\) 4,400\(tax included) if this would be less than\) \ \(4,400\) . When convertible bonds are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Convertible bonds carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as interest rate fluctuations and price fluctuations in the underlying stock. In addition, convertible bonds denominated in foreign currencies also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When bonds are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions, or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Bonds carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates. Bond prices may also fall below the invested principal as a result of such factors as changes in the management and financial circumstances of the issuer, or changes in third- party valuations of the bond in question. In addition, foreign currency- denominated bonds also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When Japanese government bonds (JGBs) for individual investors are purchased via public offerings, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. As a rule, JGBs for individual investors may not be sold in the first 12 months after issuance. When JGBs for individual investors are sold before maturity, an amount calculated via the following formula will be subtracted from the par value of the bond plus accrued interest: (1) for 10- year variable rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) \(x 0.79685\) will be used, (2) for 5- year and 3- year fixed rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) \(x 0.79685\) will be used. When inflation- indexed JGBs are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions (uridashi deals), or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Inflation- indexed JGBs carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates and fluctuations in the nationwide consumer price index. The notional principal of inflation- indexed JGBs changes in line with the rate of change in nationwide CPI inflation from the time of its issuance. The amount of the coupon payment is calculated by multiplying the coupon rate by the notional principal at the time of payment. The maturity value is the amount of the notional principal when the issue becomes due. For J117 and subsequent issues, the maturity value shall not undercut the face amount. Purchases of investment trusts (and sales of some investment trusts) are subject to a purchase or sales fee of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount. Also, a direct cost that may be incurred when selling investment trusts is a fee of up to \(2.0\%\) of the unit price at the time of redemption. Indirect costs that may be incurred during the course of holding investment trusts include, for domestic investment trusts, an asset management fee (trust fee) of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included/annualized basis) of the net assets in trust, as well as fees based on investment performance. Other indirect costs may also be incurred. For foreign investment trusts, indirect fees may be incurred during the course of holding such as investment company compensation.

Investment trusts invest mainly in securities such as Japanese and foreign equities and bonds, whose prices fluctuate. Investment trust unit prices fluctuate owing to price fluctuations in the underlying assets and to foreign exchange rate fluctuations. As such, investment trusts carry the risk of losses. Fees and risks vary by investment trust. Maximum applicable fees are subject to change; please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as prospectuses or documents delivered before making a contract.

In interest rate swap transactions and USD/JPY basis swap transactions ("interest rate swap transactions, etc."), only the agreed transaction payments shall be made on the settlement dates. Some interest rate swap transactions, etc. may require pledging of margin collateral. In some of these cases, transaction payments may exceed the amount of collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the transaction. Interest rate swap transactions, etc. carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in market prices in the interest rate, currency and other markets, as well as reference indices. Losses incurred as such may exceed the value of margin collateral, in which case margin calls may be triggered. In the event that both parties agree to enter a replacement (or termination) transaction, the interest rates received (paid) under the new arrangement may differ from those in the original arrangement, even if terms other than the interest rates are identical to those in the original transaction. Risks vary by transaction. Please thoroughly read the written materials
provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract and disclosure statements.

In OTC transactions of credit default swaps (CDS), no sales commission will be charged. When entering into CDS transactions, the protection buyer will be required to pledge or entrust an agreed amount of margin collateral. In some of these cases, the transaction payments may exceed the amount of margin collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the financial position of the protection buyer. CDS transactions carry the risk of losses owing to changes in the credit position of some or all of the referenced entities, and/or fluctuations of the interest rate market. The amount the protection buyer receives in the event that the CDS is triggered by a credit event may undercut the total amount of premiums that he/she has paid in the course of the transaction. Similarly, the amount the protection seller pays in the event of a credit event may exceed the total amount of premiums that he/she has received in the transaction. All other conditions being equal, the amount of premiums that the protection buyer pays and that received by the protection seller shall differ. In principle, CDS transactions will be limited to financial instruments business operators and qualified institutional investors. Transfers of equities to another securities company via the Japan Securities Depository Center are subject to a transfer fee of up to ¥11,000 (tax included) per issue transferred depending on volume. No account fee will be charged for marketable securities or monies deposited.

Financial instruments firm registered with the Kanto Local Finance Bureau (registration No. 142) Member associations: Japan Securities Dealers Association; Japan Investment Advisers Association; The Financial Futures Association of Japan; and Type II Financial Instruments Firms Association.
